title: 107_hr542
content:
The Act may be cited as the "Small Business Review Panel Technical Amendments Act of 1999". The Congress finds that a vibrant small business sector is crucial for job creation in the economy, with small businesses facing a disproportionate share of regulatory burdens. Federal agencies must consider the impact of regulations on small businesses early in the rulemaking process. The Small Business Advocacy Review Panel process has been effective in allowing small businesses to participate in developing rules by EPA and OSHA. The purposes of this Act are to provide a forum for effective small business participation. The purposes of this Act are to provide a forum for effective small business participation in the Federal regulatory process, clarify and strengthen the Small Business Advocacy Review Panel process, and expand the number of Federal agencies required to convene Small Business Advocacy Review Panels. SEC. 3. Ensuring full analysis of potential impacts on small entities of rules proposed by certain agencies. Section 609(b) of title 5, United States Code, is amended to require covered agencies to notify the Chief Counsel for Advocacy of the Small Business Administration before publishing an initial regulatory flexibility analysis. This includes providing information on the potential impacts of the proposed rule on small entities and identifying affected small entity representatives within 30 days. The covered agencies must notify the Chief Counsel for Advocacy of the Small Business Administration before publishing an initial regulatory flexibility analysis. This involves providing information on the potential impacts of the proposed rule on small entities and identifying affected small entity representatives within 30 days. Additionally, a review panel consisting of federal employees from relevant offices will be convened to review the prepared material for the proposed rule. The review panel, consisting of federal employees, will review material prepared by covered agencies for proposed rules. Small entity representatives will provide advice on specific issues and may make oral presentations to the panel. The panel must report to the agency head within 60 days on comments received from small entities. The review panel, composed of federal employees, will assess materials for proposed rules from covered agencies. Small entity representatives will offer advice on specific issues and may present orally to the panel. The panel must report to the agency head within 60 days on comments from small entities. The head of the agency will publish the panel's report in the Federal Register within 120 days of receiving it or as part of the proposed rule's notice of proposed rulemaking. The agency will adjust the draft proposed rule, initial regulatory flexibility analysis, or decision as needed. The review panel, composed of federal employees, assesses materials for proposed rules from covered agencies. Small entity representatives provide advice and may present orally to the panel. The panel reports comments from small entities to the agency head within 60 days. The agency head publishes the panel's report in the Federal Register within 120 days or as part of the proposed rule's notice. The agency adjusts the draft proposed rule, initial regulatory flexibility analysis, or decision as necessary. SEC. 4. DEFINITIONS.

Section 609(d) of title 5, United States Code, is amended to define 'covered agency' as the Environmental Protection Agency, the Occupational Safety and Health Administration of the Department of Labor, and the Internal Revenue Service of the Department of the Treasury, and 'small entity representative' as a small entity or an individual/organization representing a small entity.

SEC. 5. EFFECTIVE DATE.

This Act will be effective after a 90-day period from its enactment.
